subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: On PALM
msgSnippet: ... Good. I m glad to see others agree with me here. I need to point out that using one of the ligatures may not be the best solution. A font uses ligatures
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:

>
> This is an extremely good point. But I believe it is actually because
> Utter is terribly overloaded representing 1. unstressed indefinite
> vowels and 2. sampa /V/ and 3. part of the "ligature" for NURSE.
>
> Thus the problem may not be with the vowel+Roe arrangements per se but
> with Utter in particular. (I believe the "Ed-Roar vs Age-Roar" issue
> you mention is merely because Et and Eight before Roe are ambiguous
> for everyone.)
>
> The first Shaw alphabet had separate letters for vowels + Roe just as
> you suggest but they introduce a whole new set of very serious
> problems. I'm certain this is why Read abandon them in QS. I think
> fixing Utter will fix the apparent problems with vowels + Roe and
> several other issues.

Good. I'm glad to see others agree with me here. I need to point out
that using one of the ligatures may not be the best solution. A font
uses ligatures automatically, I believe. So when it finds the
combination of Ado Roar, it substitutes Earth, (if the font is designed
with ligatures, which mine is not, at least yet). It can't distinguish
when to use it and when not to use it. That means that we need a
separate letter sequence for the font to use the ligature Earth. We have
special keys for the ligatures for the ASCII QS fonts, but no keys for
the Unicode in the private area, nor any area for the new Unicode
proposal. So with Unicode, there is no way to use ligatures except by
having the font do it automatically. This lack of ability is why I have
kind of hinted that we need another sequence for Ado + Roar, and maybe
even one or two more for some of the other vowels + Roar.

However, I see you are going down a different path, trying to shift some
of the load off Ado. That sounds promising.

Paul
